title: Help with wood movement
author: No-Lavishness6942
text:
I posted this question with photos of my finished cutting board and didn't get any answers, so posting again.  
I made an end grain cutting board. The wood had all been in my shop for weeks or months before use. I ended up with two issues.

1. The board cupped after glue up, so I ran it through the timesaver to flatten it. A week later it was cupped again, just slightly. See the cut off slice photo - what would cause this? The board itself only cupped a little 1/16" but still an issue. (ignore the gap, had a little snipe I had to cut off the end of this piece.)
2. I used the same glue in all the glue ups. Titebond III. During final sanding, I wet it down (quite wet) several times to raise the grain. Sanded to 320 - glass smooth. After washing the first time and drying, I could feel just slightly many of the joints from the second to last and last glue ups. So not the five pieces into a square, but the squares into a long-grain piece then the final end-grain glue up. What would cause this? It didn't feel as if one side of the joint was proud, almost as if the glue swelled and was just slightly proud. Again, not too big a deal, my wife won't ever notice, but I notice every single time I touch it.

title: Can anyone help me with random orbital sander issues and maybe some explanations
author: Stormz_
text:
So I posted in the cutting boards subreddit recently asking for help with an end grain walnut board where every time my sander crossed over where I had just sanded, like the crossover in a Venn diagram, I was getting lines. It wasn’t an issue from what lowers grits as every time I’d sand new lines would only appear where I’d just sanded. 

I tried everything people suggested, went down the grits then back up, water popped, little to no pressure, moving nice and slow. Tried it all with no luck. Just now as a last ditch effort to see if I could make anything work I just tried moving the sander way quicker and in big circles instead of just slow in straight lines and results are way way better, I’m not getting these lines anymore. 

Can anyone please explain what’s going on? I followed all the advice that gets passed around and couldn’t get the results I wanted and yet when I threw it all out the window it somehow worked? Is it a skill issue on my part when I’m following conventional advice, is it the sander itself? Last pieces of info is the sander is a cheap, €43, Mac Allister random orbital, bought it in the hope I could start making some money to eventually invents in better tools as money is tight right now. The lines I’m talking about are circled in blue, I’m aware there are also swirl marks on the board, I had just tried a lower speed on the sander to see if that would help just before taking the pics. 

Any feedback would be great, thanks

title: Table Saw Kickback Scare - Need Safety Advice
author: AllyInCourt
text:
Hey everyone,

Had my first (and hopefully last) table saw kickback today. Seriously think my regular glasses saved my eye. It was my first time back at the saw in four years (just finished school), and I was excited to finally have time to build a little bunny toolbox for my niece's first birthday. Now I'm pretty freaked out.

The irony? I was *trying* to build a table saw sled for safety! I was making a 30-degree angle cut on a 6.5" long 2x4 (for a handle) and it shot backwards. I was pushing it with another longer 2x4 on top, between the blade and the fence. The piece is gone somewhere in my garage.

So, what now? How can I make my table saw safer? I'm hesitant to go back out there. Is it okay for a beginner to build a simple sled/jig using just a 2x4 and plywood with my zero-play miter bars (instead of complex angled plans)? Or are there affordable pre-made safety solutions I should consider? What other safety measures are crucial (like feather boards)?

Any advice would be hugely appreciated. Woodworking is my stress relief, and I don't want this fear to make me quit.

title: Have you ever experienced kickback on the table saw? What happened and what did you learn from it?
author: relentless-rookie
text:
Yesterday I posted about feeling anxious using my table saw (a Craftsman 113) even while taking all the usual safety precautions—splitter, push sticks, no freehand cuts, etc. The responses were super helpful and got me thinking more deeply about kickback in particular.

I haven’t experienced it yet (and hope I never do), but I’ve read enough to know it’s one of the scariest and most common risks. Still, I feel like real-world examples—what caused it, what the setup was, and what people learned—would help drive the lessons home more than just reading safety articles or watching YouTube.

TL;DR
Have you ever had a kickback on the table saw? What were you doing, and what do you think caused it? What did you take away from the experience?

Hoping this thread can become something that helps other woodworkers avoid the same situations—or at least better understand the warning signs.

title: Jointing and stacking timber for planters.
author: fortunate_folly
text:
Hey.

Apologies for the basic question but I've become lost in a sea of probably irrelevant variables. Some help in getting back on track would be super welcome.

Key criteria are:
- Simplicity. I'm using construction timber and they are 'just' planters
- Speed
- Strength - able to survive the inevitable rigours of outdoor life. Moisture, temperature variations, weight.
- Low maintenance.

My head is at:

- Clamp and glue but with biscuits (Not sure biscuits will add much to this scenario)

title: A gift for mother's day!
author: Horror-Assumption217
text: I've been wanting to get into woodworking for a while now, and for my first project, I decided to make a mailbox for my Mom. I used one cedar 1"x8"x8' for most of it, and an oak dowel for attaching the bottom to the walls. The hinges for the door, are hidden under the bottom. For the flag, I used some thin plywood I had lying around, and used a thin brass rod for it to pivot on. I managed to make quite a few non-lining up joints, but the only noticeable one was the top of the roof, for that I used a section of brass rod to turn it into an accent. And for all the bad joints, I used some caulk on the inside to seal them. For finish, I used some tung oil. For tools, I used all hand tools, with the exception of a power drill. Hope you guys like this, and I would appreciate all feedback.

title: Helped the kids make a scrap wood Wall-E pot holder for Mother’s Day.
author: ColonialSand-ers
text:
My son saw one of these recently and really wanted to make it for Mother’s Day so yesterday we got to work. 

I started by drawing out the basic shapes and spray gluing them to a piece of basswood. 

Then I used the bandsaw to cut them to rough shapes. 

Next we broke out the Delta Bros to get everything sanded up. 

We used a forstner bit to make depressions for the eyes. 

Then turned a scrap of basswood round for the next. I added a 0.5” tenon to connect to the body. 

I used a chunk of maple for the body to give it some weight to balance the pot. 

I cut a half lap into our neck dowel for the crossbar to hold the eyes to sit on. 

I used a piece of cherry for the platform and cut a depression in it with another forstner bit for the pot to rest in. 

Finally we connected everything up with glue and dowels.
